titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Dickson Family Papers, 1769-1924
titlestmt.subtitle: Dickson Family Papers Ms1998-094

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-10-24 10:01:09-0400

titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections Ms1998-094

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Dickson Family Papers must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dickson Family Papers, 1869-1924, Ms1988-094, Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Dicksons were pioneer settlers of Greenbrier County, Virginia (now West Virginia). Joseph Dickson (1749-1822) settled in what is now Greenbrier County, West Virginia, from Ireland by way of Pennsylvania in the 1770s. He received land grants originally from the King's land office in 1769, and later from the Commonwealth of Virginia in 1785, 1789, and 1795 for property on Howard's Creek. His son, Robert Dickson (1795-1869?), inherited the land and built Locust Hill in 1833, now called Mountain Home. Robert Renick Dickson (1827-1888) and Henry Frazier Dickson (1841-1909), Robert Dickson's sons, inherited the land and in turn left it to their heirs. The Dicksons turned Mountain Home near White Sulphur Springs into a resort in the 1800s and early 1900s. The property and home were owned by the family until they were sold in 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist largely of land, property, and goods transaction receipts and documents of each of the four generations of the family represented. Certificates, oaths, correspondence, deeds, and a diary are included in Joseph Dickson's papers, along with several slave sale documents from the late 1700s and early 1800s. Many of the land, slave, and goods exchanged were with neighbors and others in the area. Most of Joseph Dickson's documents are individually described in this inventory. The papers of John Dickson (1737-1809, brother of Joseph Dickson), Robert Dickson, Robert Renick Dickson and Henry Frazier Dickson, and Geraldine Dickson Burrow (1879-1943, daughter of Henry Frazier Dickson), are grouped by type of material (for example, financial accounts, correspondence, and land deeds). Within Robert Dickson's correspondence are a few references to the Civil War, including a letter from a Confederate tax collector demanding payment of his 1863 Confederate taxes. Other interesting documents include the transcript (1916) of the trial of Sallie Dickson (wife of Robert Renick Dickson) who was sued by Henry Frazier Dickson, for payment of rent due to him. The papers also include genealogy charts of the family.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged by family member, and then chronologically by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate asserting that Joseph Dickson was received in his parish and "has behaved himself in a Verry prudent and exemplary manner," signed by M. Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate stating that Joseph Tooth knows Joseph Dickson "...to be of good respectable character...and believe him to be of untainted moral character..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate asserting that Joseph Dickson lived in Greenbrier County, Virginia, for four years and "Behaved himself as an honast man aught to Do."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oath to the General Assembly [of Virginia] taken by Joseph Dickson, signed by Geo. Skillem

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Marriage certificate of Joseph Dickson and Mary Yung, married March 5, 1772, signed by McHoy(?) in Lebanontown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate signed by John Dickinson of Augusta County, Virginia, as to Joseph Dickson's good character when Dickson lived on Dickinson's land.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate that Joseph Dickson resided in the Spreading(?) congregation from 1779 to 1780, and "behaved himself sober and in an inoffensive manner," signed by Edward Crawford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Statement of falsely accusing John Wevans "with taking goods out of the store of Francis Mara" made by Mary Wave.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate that Joseph Dickson (son of Joseph Sr.) has lived in East Hanover, Pennsylvania, and learned the hatter trade, signed by Daniel Bradley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificate of military service, signed by Capt. James Smith (n.d.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From unknown asking Joseph Dickson to give John Humphrys his bond.

scopecontent.p: J. Patton to Joseph Dickson for flour sold; Jas. Richards to Joseph Dickson, asking him to send a hat (?) he left for Dickson with Samuel Ruiker or Jas. Kincaid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.p: Financial accounts, 1771-79; 22 items. Receipts for money received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial accounts, 1780-89; 27 items. Household goods purchased, receipt for 1779 taxes paid by Dickson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Papers (1775-1810, n.d.); 20 items (including medical cure recipes for the flux, rheumatism, "stomic ake," snake bite, colic, and others, and accounts, receipts, and a warrant from James Alexander to the sheriff of Monroe County, Virginia, concerning John Dickson).

scopecontent.p: 33 items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 36 items (includes a letter from the tax collector of the 62nd Virginia district demanding payment of Dickson's 1863 Confederate taxes; and the draft of a letter, dated September 18, 1865, from Robert Dickson to President Andrew Johnson, vowing his allegiance to the government of the U.S.A. and asking for a "release from the penalties and forfictures to which I am exposed.")
